If a 164-ft wide asteroid was estimated to miss the Earth by only 30,000 miles, more than a month from now? how confident would you feel that it would actually miss us? Would you trust the calculated trajectory with so close a near miss? And how much damage would a rock that size do anyway? 
 
 http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2007/21dec_2007wd5.htm?list1043372

post_info.post_title: Mars is in for a near miss, if their lucky that is...

If a 164-ft wide asteroid was estimated to miss the Earth by only 30,000 miles, more than a month from now? how confident would you feel that it would actually miss us? Would you trust the calculated trajectory with so close a near miss? And how much damage would a rock that size do anyway? 
 
 http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2007/21dec_2007wd5.htm?list1043372

 
 I would be fairly confident that it would miss us. The article says a 1 in 75 chance of a collision. If it were to hit the Earth rather than Mars, the damage would be less simply because we have a much more dense atmosphere, meaning far more of it would burn up before actual contact. Mars, if hit, would take greater damage. Might set back their planned invasion though, so here's hoping.
 
 Smiley
Earth has 1.9 times Mars' diameter, and more than 9 times its mass. A calculated miss of 30,000 miles would have a much, much worse than 1 in 75 chance of hitting us.
